note.para: See Where to report to submit new bugs or patches.

section.title: Current bugs and patches
section.para: A good way to get involved.
As soon as a gtkmm patch has been clearly approved by a maintainer, anybody with git write access may apply it.

listitem.para: Bugs are tracked in GNOME's issue tracker. Submit gtkmm bugs here.

Patches should be attached to existing issues or MRs (merge requests) rather than sent to GNOME's Discourse forum. When reporting a new bug you'll get a chance to attach a file to it immediately after opening the issue.

section.title: What information is needed for a bug report?

listitem.para: version numbers of GTK, gtkmm and other related software, including your platform/distro/compiler.
stack dump, if relevant: gdb ./proggy ; run ; *crash* ; where

section.para: If we can't solve the problem immediately then we might ask you to create a simple-as-possible example that actually builds. This helps us to isolate the problem, and proves that the problem is not caused by your own code.

section.title: How do I create a patch?
section.para: There are many ways to use Git, but this is the simplest way to create a patch if you are unfamiliar with Git:

listitem.para: Use git to create a patch git diff -u > my_fix.patch
Add the patch in the issue tracker (see above).

section.title: Should I send a bug report?

listitem.para: If you get a crash and you think it might be problem with gtkmm.
If you have a good idea of how to make gtkmm better.

section.para:
If you know how to fix the bug, you can
create a merge request instead of (or in addition to) an issue.
